item.title: Bill Cosby’s Sexual Assault Case Ends in a Mistrial
item.media:description: Bill Cosby, center, stands with his spokesman Andrew Wyatt, left, outside of the Montgomery County Courthouse in Norristown, Pa.
item.description: After the jury could not come to verdict after six days of deliberations, the judge in the sexual assault trial declared a mistrial.
item.dc:creator: GRAHAM BOWLEY, RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and JON HURDLE

item.title: Why Couldn’t the Cosby Jury Reach a Verdict? Legal Experts Assess
item.media:description: The Montgomery County Courthouse in Norristown, Pa., during Bill Cosby’s sexual assault trial.
item.description: Lawyers and law professors analyzing the mistrial pointed to inconsistencies in testimony and the difficulties of persuading one or more recalcitrant jurors.
item.dc:creator: SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: Trump’s Business Ties in Persian Gulf Raise Questions About His Allegiances
item.media:description: Along the motorcade route for President Trump, on the way to the airport in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, where he recently attended a summit meeting.
item.description: In the feud among Arab nations, President Trump has supported the ones with which he does business.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Trump Attacks Rosenstein in Latest Rebuke of Justice Department
item.media:description: President Trump with Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, his national security adviser, on Friday. The president wrote on Twitter, in reference to the deputy attorney general: “I am being investigated for firing the FBI Director by the man who told me to fire the FBI Director!”
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.description: The president is increasingly at odds with the Justice Department and the F.B.I. as the investigation into Russian election interference expands.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR, CHARLIE SAVAGE and MAGGIE HABERMAN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Education Dept. Says It Will Scale Back Civil Rights Investigations
item.media:description: Betsy DeVos, the education secretary, has denounced discrimination, but has signaled that her office is “not going to be issuing any decrees” on civil rights.
item.description: The department will not consider civil rights investigations mandatory, loosening rules that spurred broad looks at issues from sexual assault to disciplinary actions.
item.dc:creator: ERICA L. GREEN

item.title: Mueller, Sessions and Cuba: Trump News of the Week
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with his cabinet on Monday.
item.description: Worried that you missed an important political story this week? You’re not alone. Catch up on a very busy week of news.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by ERIN SEIMS

item.title: Trump’s Businesses Show Mixed Returns During Campaign and Presidency
item.media:description: President Trump returned to the White House on Friday after an event in Miami. The disclosures of Mr. Trump’s private finances have significant limitations and lack the level of detail normally provided in tax returns.
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.description: Revenue from several holdings from his global business enterprises rose substantially in the last year, while others were flat or lower
item.dc:creator: STEVE EDER, ERIC LIPTON and ANDREW W. LEHREN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Before the Gunfire in Virginia, a Volatile Home Life in Illinois
item.media:description: The Hodgkinsons’ home in Belleville, Ill. James T. Hodgkinson spent much of his adult life in the town, a community of just over 40,000 people not far from St. Louis.
item.media:credit: Michael B. Thomas/Getty Images North America
item.description: James T. Hodgkinson had a troubled life before he drove halfway across the country to shoot at members of Congress at a baseball practice.
item.dc:creator: JULIE TURKEWITZ, SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, JOHN ELIGON and ALAN BLINDER

item.title: Rooting for Scalise Through Hospital Ordeal: His 3 Capitol Roommates
item.media:description: A group showed support for Representative Steve Scalise after the Congressional Baseball Game in Washington on Thursday.
item.description: While the lawmaker continues to grapple with extensive injuries after being shot last week, his housemates stay hopeful and cautiously plan for a homecoming.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Rescuers Search for 7 Sailors as Damaged U.S. Destroyer Reaches Port
item.media:description: The USS Fitzgerald returned to Yokosuka Naval Base with the help of tugboats after its collision with the container ship ACX Crystal off the coast of Yokosuka, Japan.
item.description: Aided by tugboats and with water pouring into its hull, the destroyer returned to an American naval base after colliding with a cargo ship off Japan.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE, MOTOKO RICH and ANDY NEWMAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Guilty Verdict for Young Woman Who Urged Friend to Kill Himself
item.description: Michelle Carter, who pressed Conrad Roy III to kill himself, was convicted in a rare finding that a person’s words can directly cause someone else’s suicide.
item.dc:creator: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and JESS BIDGOOD

item.title: After Tragedy, Healing a Charleston Church
item.description: On June 17, 2015, nine people were shot and killed inside Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C. In this 360° video, stand with the congregation during a Sunday service.

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: A Mother’s Death, a Botched Inquiry and a Sheriff at War
item.media:description: Rusty Rodgers, a special agent with the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. His review of a closed case would upend his life.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: The sheriff called it a suicide. When a state investigator raised questions, he became the investigated.
item.dc:creator: WALT BOGDANICH

item.title: Whole Foods Deal Shows Amazon’s Prodigious Tolerance for Risk
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, at the Space Symposium in Colorado Springs in April. His embrace of risk and experimentation has included the development of reusable rockets.
item.media:credit: Nick Cote for The New York Times
item.description: A longtime approach of making bold — and sometimes head-scratching — moves has brought Jeff Bezos staggering success.
item.dc:creator: DAVID STREITFELD

item.title: Robot Revolution: Amazon’s Move Signals End of Line for Many Cashiers
item.media:description: Shoppers in line at a Brooklyn Whole Foods. The grocery store of the future may not have checkout lines or cashiers.
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.description: The next jobs set to disappear may be ones that are a bigger part of people’s daily lives: retail workers and cashiers in stores and restaurants.
item.dc:creator: CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: State of the Art: In Whole Foods, Bezos Gets a Sustainably Sourced Guinea Pig
item.description: By purchasing the upscale chain, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief, has a chance to tinker with how people buy groceries — and map the future of the physical store.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Rooted in Counterculture, Whole Foods’ Founder Finds an Unlikely Refuge
item.media:description: John Mackey, Whole Foods’ chief, had long resisted its sale.
item.description: John Mackey wanted to fight off the activist investors attacking Whole Foods. He found a savior in Amazon, a company blamed for laying waste to retailers.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: As Uber Leaders Step Aside, Arianna Huffington’s Influence Grows
item.media:description: Arianna Huffington, left center, with Bozoma A. Saint John, Uber’s chief brand officer, in San Francisco. Ms. Huffington, a member of Uber’s board, is playing a growing role in the company as it contends with a string of scandals.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: In the 14 months since she joined the board, Ms. Huffington has been a public voice for the start-up and a confidante to its chief executive.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Grim Echoes for Families: An Officer Shoots and a Jury Acquits
item.media:description: Supporters of Philando Castile marched along University Avenue in St. Paul on Friday night after a vigil at Minnesota’s State Capitol.
item.media:credit: Anthony Souffle/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.description: A Minnesota police officer was acquitted in the shooting of Philando Castile, and some families saw a pattern. Few officers are charged, and fewer still convicted.
item.dc:creator: MITCH SMITH, YAMICHE ALCINDOR and JACK HEALY

item.title: Minnesota Officer Acquitted in Killing of Philando Castile
item.media:description: Family and friends of Valerie Castile and Philando Castile, including John Thompson, center, wept as he walked out of the courthouse after Jeronimo Yanez was found not guilty on all counts in the shooting death of Philando Castile.
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Flores/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.description: The officer fatally shot Philando Castile, a black motorist, during a traffic stop last summer. Mr. Castile’s girlfriend live-streamed the aftermath.
item.dc:creator: MITCH SMITH

item.title: Election Success for Emmanuel Macron May Mask Real Challenges
item.media:description: Sarah El Haïry, 28, a political newcomer, campaigning in Heric, France. The candidate hopes to draw on the good will for France’s new president, Emmanuel Macron.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: France’s new president appears on the verge of getting a lot of support in Parliament, but he may not have a lot of time to win over the French people.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: U.S. Open Grass Is an Obstacle and a Potential Health Hazard
item.media:description: From left, Jimmy Walker, Justin Thomas and Rickie Fowler at Erin Hills, which features thick fescue grass, a hospitable spot for bugs like ticks.
item.description: Erin Hills’s thick fescue presents a challenge to players, but is also a hospitable spot for ticks, prompting concern about Lyme disease.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: 13 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
item.description: Take a break with stories about raccoon attacks, the business of waiting in line and yoga classes with cats.
item.dc:creator: ANNA DUBENKO and MICHELLE L. DOZOIS

item.title: 58 Presumed Dead in London Tower Blaze, Police Say
item.media:description: Residents near Grenfell Tower on Saturday. The police said that the death toll from the inferno at the tower in west London had risen to 58.
item.description: The increase in the toll came as the queen said Britain was trapped in a “somber national mood” after a series of tragedies.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: 7 U.S. Soldiers Wounded in Insider Attack in Afghanistan
item.description: The attack at Camp Shaheen in the north was the second such “green on blue” attack in a week.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Carrie Fisher Died From Sleep Apnea and Other Factors, Coroner Says
item.media:description: Carrie Fisher in Los Angeles in 2011. The actor died after suffering a medical emergency on an international flight in December.
item.description: The Los Angeles County coroner’s office said investigators have not been able to determine an exact cause of death for the actor who died in December.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As Asian Scorchers Multiply, Records Fall and Attention Rises
item.media:description: People cooling off in Quetta, Pakistan, this month. The remote town of Turbat, in the same province of Baluchistan, experienced one of the hottest days on record on May 28: 129.2 degrees Fahrenheit.
item.description: Asia may have recently recorded its highest temperature ever: 129.2 degrees Fahrenheit. Interest in such records is growing alongside climate-change awareness.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and MIKE IVES

item.title: Merkel Says Pope Francis Urged Her to Fight for Paris Climate Accord
item.media:description: Pope Francis receives Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, along with her husband Joachim Sauer, left, on Saturday during a private audience at the Vatican.
item.description: Germany’s chancellor also said that the pope shared her aim to “bring down walls,” not build them, an apparent reference to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Not Your Mother’s Jersey Shore
item.media:description: Empty lots along the oceanfront in Mantoloking, N.J.
item.description: Five years after Hurricane Sandy destroyed communities along the shore, some towns have used the rebuilding process as a time to reinvent themselves.
item.dc:creator: JILL P. CAPUZZO

item.title: Can Animals Predict Earthquakes? Italian Farm Acts as a Lab to Find Out
item.media:description: Florindo Angeli, right, and his son removing a tag from a sheep at their farm in Pieve Torina, Italy, in April. Animals at the farm had worn the solar-powered tags for months as part of an experiment to monitor their behavior before earthquakes.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: A scientist hopes to learn, by tagging animals in Italy, whether they could be used as an effective warning system before an earthquake.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: That Decisive Moment: Mahler, Transformed: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.description: "Swan Lake," the New York Philharmonic and an operatic "Angels in America" were among the highlights.

item.title: Iran Bans Zumba, and Its Fans Fume
item.media:description: Zumba-themed wristbands.
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.description: An Iranian government institution promoting sports and a healthy lifestyle effectively banned Zumba classes for being contrary to Islamic precepts.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Le Pen Loses Luster, Signaling Far Right’s Retreat in France, and Maybe Beyond
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Front party in France, speaking at a rally in Calais last week before the first round of parliamentary elections.
item.description: After Marine Le Pen was crushed in the presidential election, her party is faring dismally in legislative elections and squabbling over strategy.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: On Golf: Golfer Known as ‘Beef’ Has PB&J and No Complaints
item.media:description: Andrew Johnston, 28, on the ninth hole on Friday. Johnston, who brings a childlike joy to the game, is part of an Arby’s advertising campaign.
item.description: Andrew Johnston, who was two under par after two rounds at the United States Open, has endeared himself to fans with his good-natured personality.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: Two Protesters Disrupt ‘Julius Caesar’ in Central Park
item.media:description: People arrived for Shakespeare in the Park’s production of “Julius Caesar” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Monday.
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A production of the Shakespeare play was interrupted by protesters objecting to a scene where a character resembling President Trump is murdered.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: The Los Angeles Philharmonic Lost Its Leader. Can It Stay on Top?
item.media:description: The Walt Disney Concert Hall, home to the Los Angeles Philharmonic; the orchestra, well financed and with a series of daring programs, is regrouping as its chief executive, Deborah Borda, departs for New York.
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.description: Deborah Borda, who helped make the orchestra the envy of the music world, left for the New York Philharmonic. But nobody in Los Angeles seems worried.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL COOPER

item.title: Brooklyn, as Hollywood Never Sees It
item.media:description: The director Jim McKay, who is unveiling his first feature film in 12 years, “En El Séptimo Día” (“On the Seventh Day”).
item.description: Jim McKay’s new film, about bicycle delivery men and soccer in Carroll Gardens and Sunset Park, is having its premiere at BAMcinemaFest.
item.dc:creator: MIKE HALE

item.title: Update: How to Travel to Cuba Now
item.media:credit: Robert Rausch for The New York Times
item.description: The Trump administration may impose stricter rules for visiting Cuba. Here’s how those could affect travelers.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
